titleStmt.title: Sir Iohn Presbyter not dead. As the malicious author of that abusive pamphlet, that nine-dayes-wonder lately printed, intituled, The last will and testament of Sir John Presbyter, divulged. But was onely bereft of his soule for a few dayes, and is now againe revived. The wondrous things he saw, during his confinement to the lower parts. What committee-men, commanders, and ministers, hee saw there grievously tormented. Faithfully taken from his owne mouth. Reade and wonder.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 11 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 6 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Sir Iohn Presbyter not dead. As the malicious author of that abusive pamphlet, that nine-dayes-wonder lately printed, intituled, The last will and testament of Sir John Presbyter, divulged. But was onely bereft of his soule for a few dayes, and is now againe revived. The wondrous things he saw, during his confinement to the lower parts. What committee-men, commanders, and ministers, hee saw there grievously tormented. Faithfully taken from his owne mouth. Reade and wonder.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Thomas Tantalus for Christopher Charon, and are to be sold at his shop in the shades of Dis, at the signe of the Gorgons head,

notesStmt.note: The imprint is false. Actual place and publication date from Wing.
"Includes a ballad: 'What if the King'"--Thomason Catalogue.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As the malicious Author of that abuÅ¿ive Pamphlet, that nine-dayes-wonder lately Printed, intituled,
The Last Will and teÅ¿tament of Sir John Presbyter, divulged.
But was onely bereft of his Å¿oule for a few dayes, and is now againe revived.
The wondrous things he Å¿aw, during his confinement to the lower parts.
What Committee-men, Commanders, and MiniÅ¿ters, hee Å¿aw there grievouÅ¿ly tormented.
Faithfully taken from his owne mouth.
Aug: 20 GEHENNA, Printed by Thomas Tantalus for ChriÅ¿topher Charon, and are to be Å¿old at his Å¿hop in the Å¿hades of Dis, at the Å¿igne of the Gorgons head.

div.head: Sir JOHN PRESBYTER not Dead.
div.p: ALas, alas, Independents, and am I againe revived; I live againe, and Å¿hall doe Å¿o, till I behold the Babel you have builded, demoliÅ¿hed by your Å¿elves, and your Anarchy bee reduced to Monarchy: The hyreling you imployed to publiÅ¿h my Death, is Å¿ince dead himÅ¿elfe; alas the fellow was Å¿mitten with the horror of his crime, and not able to indure the thoughts Pluto continually Å¿uggeÅ¿ted; hee, like one weary of his Fetters, leaping out at the priÅ¿on window, breaketh his limbes, gave up the GhoÅ¿t. My Å¿weet friends, I have the coldeÅ¿t comfort for you, that your greateÅ¿t enemies can wiÅ¿h, during my confinement to the Å¿hades below, for to me it was permitted, as once to the righteous Lazarus, to take a view of things there done, and thence once more to viÅ¿it the Earth.

I Å¿aw neere the Lake called Phlegeton, an infinite number of RoyalliÅ¿ts, alias EpiÅ¿coparians, RomiÅ¿h Catholicks, Pimps, Panders and Parricides, kneeling before the brazen Gates of Plute's Pallace, all
with heav'd up hands, invoking the Prince of hell, to further their deÅ¿igne with his utmoÅ¿t ayde, to Å¿end his Å¿pirits abroad to Å¿educe the Å¿oules of men, that they might be perÅ¿waded, to create a hell on earth, (if it might be) to Å¿et up confuÅ¿ion, and countenance utter deÅ¿olation, to wit, Independencie, for which immunities, if it tooke effect, they joyntly Å¿wore by the river Stix, to Å¿tuffe hell with more Å¿ouls, then the Å¿aid river harboured Serpents, and with themÅ¿elves, to draw the world after them to deÅ¿truction: The principal Å¿ticklers in this buÅ¿ines, my thoughts perÅ¿waded me repreÅ¿ented the perÅ¿ons of a famous ApoÅ¿tate, now a houÅ¿e preacher, alias TubiÅ¿t in Bell-Alley; and of another ApoÅ¿tle of the new Edition, a Å¿educer, who daily giveth deÅ¿truction, I mean inÅ¿truction, neer Finsbury; I had a Å¿ight of SaltmarÅ¿h, but he as a Å¿hadow flying away, fled from me; there were divers others, which for brevity I Å¿hall omit, who were unceÅ¿Å¿antly urgent on Lucifer, to lend them his ayde, when Goodwin was allotted by the whole multitude to Å¿peake in the name of them all, who Å¿aid:

Thou knowÅ¿t great Prince, how I with theÅ¿e my Brethren, have for many yeeres oppoÅ¿ed even the high Court of Parliament, aÅ¿Å¿embled in the chiefe City of England, to aboliÅ¿h EpiÅ¿copacy, and Å¿et up Presbytery, hath bin their chiefe ayme, and yet by us have hitherto bin continually thwarted in their Å¿ayings, oppoÅ¿ed in their actions, and fruÅ¿trated of their deÅ¿ires, I am Å¿ure thou canÅ¿t not forget, how we have hitherto uÅ¿ed al means, and deviÅ¿ed all wayes to raiÅ¿e diÅ¿cords & diviÅ¿ions, which we know in the
end cannot but prove the diÅ¿Å¿olution of Monarchy, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently, the corner Å¿tone of Anarchy; to attaine which our deÅ¿ires, we have hired our deare Brother, and indeed, ours and thine owne Prop, John Lilburne, to perÅ¿uade the people, that even their Lord K. Charles is now captive under their Å¿overaign power; that he be forthwith Articled againÅ¿t, Impeached,Regall Tyranny, pag. 14 â¢ 6.53. Arraigned, DepoÅ¿ed, Executed, & his PoÅ¿teritie diÅ¿inherited by the Parliament; that the AÅ¿Å¿embly of Divines be immediately diÅ¿Å¿olved, and impeached of high TreaÅ¿on, Presbyteries Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed, the Directorie, Nationall League, PariÅ¿hes, PariÅ¿h Churche, Chappels, Tythes, Oblations, MiniÅ¿ters by Ordination, UniverÅ¿ities, and all Schooles, except onely Å¿uch as teach EngliÅ¿h, Write, and Cypher; all Å¿et formes of Prayer, the Lords Prayer, Creed, and Ten Commandements, Baptizing of Infants, & Å¿inging of PÅ¿alms, utterly aboliÅ¿hed: Therefore, on our part, great Prince, thou mayÅ¿t gueÅ¿Å¿e, that there hath not, nor now is, any thing wanting that may further our DeÅ¿igne, but onely thy preÅ¿ent Aid, in an eÅ¿peciall manner, now in the nick of time we implore; for now, to our unÅ¿peak â¢ b â¢ e griefe, there is like to be a free and full Parliament, who have already Voted the Man whom we Å¿o extremely hate (the King) to Lond â¢ n, there to remaine with honour and Å¿afetie: therfore, great Sir, as you tender the inlargement of your Territories, the Command of Soules, and the ruine of Mankind, deviÅ¿e Å¿ome Å¿peedie remedie, that Independencie may be tolerated, his MajeÅ¿tie prohibited from comming to London, this Parliament diÅ¿Å¿olved, and our Anaschy introduced; and this as you tender your owne honour and our Å¿afetie.

This Speech was approv'd of by the whole multitude, who expreÅ¿t their liking by a generall Å¿hout; but what anÅ¿wer Pluto returned, I cannot relate, for I was tranÅ¿ported with a deÅ¿ire to pry yet further into the Å¿ecrets of that tenebrous place; Å¿o paÅ¿Å¿ing on from thence, I came into a large Plain, where fire continually ran along upon the ground, where were many men tormented with Å¿undry torments; there I Å¿ â¢ w a company of Furies, who were buÅ¿ily imployed in preparing Wracks, Gibbets, and other various inÅ¿truments of torture; upon a Gridiron I beheld one lye, whom at the Å¿ight I took to be Quaterman, but viewing him better, I found I was deceived, for it was WanÅ¿worth the Committeeman, who gathered together the wealth of a whole County, pretending for the publike uÅ¿e, and then ran away over Sea: Neere him I beheld Å¿wimming in a Lake of Sulphure, TownÅ¿en, whom once the Parliament of England Å¿o much confided in, and now Å¿o well know his falÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e, who after hee had cheated both the publike wealth and the whole PariÅ¿h wherein hee lived, being by them complained againÅ¿t and proÅ¿ecuted, fled into the North part of England, and turn'd MiniÅ¿ter; Ah TownÅ¿en, Å¿aid I, thou never wert in Å¿uch a Tub before; and were all houÅ¿e-preachers allowed no better a Pulpit, they would have little joy to expound: Neere theÅ¿e I beheld thruÅ¿t through with Å¿words of fire, divers Commanders, that through feare or falÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e lately deÅ¿erted the Army; Pluto had an it tention to make them of his own guard, for there he feared not their fl â¢ etingâª and there they might without Å¿cruple, be as
they would themÅ¿elvs, the more baÅ¿er, the more better; neer theÅ¿e lockt in iron collers, glowing hot, I Å¿aw one Levite, whom by my gueÅ¿Å¿e I took to be the Author of Hagio MaÅ¿tix, hee much repented he left Coleman-Å¿treet for Bell-Alley, and earth for hell; the thought of the dayes he once enjoyed, when his Audience gathered him for one Sermon 20. l. doubly augmented his torments: Neer him in the Å¿ame poÅ¿ture, lay the Å¿imple author of Simplicities Defence, wall-ey'd Gorton, who wanting mony in old England, would needs be hired to go over into New England, to convert the Infidels, and after returned a perfect pagan, and ingroÅ¿Å¿ed an Audience to himÅ¿elfe, and they forÅ¿ooth were Gortons Congregation, the fat foole howled like a Lybian Lion taken in the Hunters toyle; and therfore Photo coÌmanded his throat to be filled with moken Lead, to Å¿top the paÅ¿Å¿age of his cryes; for he, as he did on earth, Å¿ought to diÅ¿turb all Hell: But by this my time limited, was expired, and my Å¿oule returned to my body, and comming on earth, and paÅ¿Å¿ing to WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter Hall, I heard a fellow Å¿ing this Ballad, called,

div.head: What if the King, &c. Or, The Armyhath helpt us.
div.l: WHen as great matters were Å¿eemingly handling,
yet order and DiÅ¿cipline pul'd to the ground,
And baÅ¿e HypocriÅ¿ie Rebellion dandling,
fooles walking at large, wiÅ¿e men in the Pound;
Loe a hand was put forth,
For to Å¿ave thoÅ¿e of worth,
Hell Å¿hreikt,
Knaves Å¿queakt,
Fearing to fall.
When most men fear'd their meat would but bane them,
and their owne hands would wound them to death,
When as the Trustees in a net had tane them,
and thoÅ¿e Å¿ought their ruine to whom they gave breath,
Then at that time when Å¿uccour was Å¿cant,
Hee that they rely'd on,
ThoÅ¿e they did confide on,
Fail'd them,
AÅ¿sail'd them,
The truth for to try.
And non the Committee-mens arÅ¿es make buttons,
and the ExciÅ¿e-men begin for to hide,
The City Churles, and paunch-belly'd Sluttons,
begin for to pauÅ¿e where they may abide,
Free from the ills that may on them fall;
The Tub-men grow hoarÅ¿e,
And forget to diÅ¿courÅ¿e,
The SiÅ¿ters are Å¿ilent, and wiÅ¿hed
They ne're
While e're
Had preacht at all.
Time-Å¿erving PrieÅ¿ts that in Pulpits reviled,
and dare to abuÅ¿e their Soveraign Lord,
Now with themÅ¿elves t â¢ him reconciled,
altring their OriÅ¿ons with one accord,
Cheap-Å¿ide-CroÅ¿Å¿e was Å¿een,
When before it had been,
Charing-CroÅ¿se was in hope,
Without leave of the Pope,
For to be new erected,
Most men,
Hop't then,
To have the old way agen.
